alt="Gov. Kevin Stitt sits at a wooden desk signing a bill; behind him are several young female athletes, some with signs that read, “Save women’s sports.”" class="css-rq4mmj" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/23/multimedia/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp&disable=upscale" srcSet="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/23/multimedia/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb-articleLarge.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 600w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/23/multimedia/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb-jumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 1024w,https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/01/23/multimedia/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb/00pol-transgender-photo01-vlzb-superJumbo.jpg?quality=75&auto=webp 2048w" sizes="((min-width: 600px) and (max-width: 1004px)) 84vw, (min-width: 1005px) 60vw, 100vw" decoding="async" width="600" height="400"/></picture></div><figcaption class="css-y5g5d7 e1maroi60"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma signing a bill last year that bars transgender girls and women from girls’ and women’s sports teams. A new bill would make it a felony to provide transition treatment to transgender people younger than 26.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Sean Murphy/Associated Press</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div><div class="css-103l8m3"><div class="css-1u5onbp epjyd6m1"><div class="css-165eim7 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/maggie-astor" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="Maggie Astor" title="Maggie Astor" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/07/18/multimedia/author-maggie-astor/author-maggie-astor-thumbLarge-v2.png" class="css-dc6zx6 ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-233int epjyd6m0"><p class="css-4anu6l e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/maggie-astor" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Maggie Astor</a></span></p></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module"><div class="css-3xqm5e"><time dateTime="2023-01-30T18:02:48-05:00" class="css-8blifj e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->Jan. 25, 2023</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->Jan. 30, 2023</span></time></div></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div><figure class="margins-h css-1vfijp3"><figcaption class="css-5soref"><div class="audioFigureHeading"><h3 class="css-m1fye1">Listen to This Article</h3></div></figcaption><div class="css-f4hvxb"><div><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"AudioObject","@id":"https://static.nytimes.com/podcasts/2023/01/30/us/25pol-transgender/230125-pol-transgender-state-lawmakers-nyt-audm.mp3","description":"","name":"Listen to This Article","contentUrl":"https://static.nytimes.com/podcasts/2023/01/30/us/25pol-transgender/230125-pol-transgender-state-lawmakers-nyt-audm.mp3","duration":"PT0.799S"}</script></div></div></figure></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, </em><a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.audm.com/?utm_source=nyt&utm_medium=embed&utm_campaign=pol_transgender_state_lawmakers" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">download Audm for iPhone or Android</em></a><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0">.</em></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Over the past three years, Republican state lawmakers have put forward a barrage of bills to regulate the lives of transgender youths, restricting the sports teams they can play on, bathrooms they can use and medical care they can receive.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But even by those standards, the start of the 2023 legislative season stands out for the aggressiveness with which lawmakers are pushing into new territory.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The bills they have proposed — more than 150 in at least 25 states — include bans on transition care into young adulthood; restrictions on drag shows using definitions that could broadly encompass performances by transgender people; measures that would prevent teachers in many cases from using names or pronouns matching students’ gender identities; and requirements that schools out transgender students to their parents.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The flood of legislation is part of a long-term campaign by national groups that see transgender rights as an issue on which they can harness voter anger — as with the campaigns against remote learning and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/01/us/politics/critical-race-theory.html" title="">critical race theory</a> that reshaped many school boards and lifted Republicans in Virginia’s elections in 2021 — though the midterm elections provided little evidence of it.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“This is a political winner,” said Terry Schilling, the president of the conservative American Principles Project, arguing that more voters would have been swayed had many Republicans not “shied away” from the subject.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The potential consequences for transgender people, for whom <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/10/us/politics/anti-transgender-lgbtq-threats-attacks.html" title="">harassment and threats have become common</a> and suicide rates are high, are profound. Many express a sense that the power of their government is being turned against them as they try to live their lives.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“We have shifted this conversation so incredibly far in the direction of restrictions on trans people’s autonomy and rights in a way that was completely unfathomable to many of us even just three or four years ago,” said Chase Strangio, a lawyer at the American Civil Liberties Union.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Legislation in <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://www.oklegislature.gov/BillInfo.aspx?Bill=sb129&Session=2300" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Oklahoma</a> and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.scstatehouse.gov/sess125_2023-2024/bills/3730.htm" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">South Carolina</a> would make it a felony to provide hormonal or surgical transition treatment to transgender people younger than 26 — an uncharted incursion into adults’ health care. Other bills in <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://www.oklegislature.gov/BillInfo.aspx?Bill=hb1011&Session=2300" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">both</a> <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.scstatehouse.gov/billsearch.php?billnumbers=0274&session=125&summary=B" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">states</a>, and in <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://kslegislature.org/li/b2023_24/measures/sb12/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Kansas</a> and <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/2023/pdf/history/HB/HB1258.xml" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Mississippi</a>, would ban such care up to age 21. And bills in more than a dozen states would ban it for minors, which Arkansas <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2021/04/06/us/biden-news-today/arkansas-anti-transgender-law-veto" title="">was the first to do</a> in 2021, against the consensus of major medical organizations.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A bill <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/documents/2023/pdf/SB/2001-2099/SB2076IN.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">in Mississippi</a> — declaring that “separate is not inherently unequal,” an allusion to Plessy v. Ferguson, the 1896 ruling in which the Supreme Court upheld segregation — would define sex as immutably set at birth, denying transgender identities under state law. A measure <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://www.wvlegislature.gov/Bill_Text_HTML/2023_SESSIONS/RS/bills/sb252%20intr.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">in West Virginia</a> would define “any transvestite and/or transgender exposure, performances or display” as obscene, potentially outlawing transgender people’s presence around children.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Not all, or perhaps even most, of the measures will become law, and those that do may face legal challenges. But as of Tuesday, more than 10 bills had made it through committee, and at least six had passed a full legislative chamber, according to Erin Reed, a legislative researcher.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">She and other transgender advocates said they worried that the most aggressive bills, even if never enacted, could ease the passage of slightly less aggressive bills by making them seem like compromises.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“I really hope that people don’t allow that to happen,” said Ms. Reed, who is transgender. “Because these bills still target trans people who will then have to suffer the consequences.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The people pushing these laws include Christian conservatives — among them some of the same figures who fought the legalization of gay marriage — and political operatives. They have organized and lobbied through groups like the Alliance Defending Freedom, the Family Policy Alliance, the Heritage Foundation and the American Principles Project.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Many bills contain nearly identical language, suggesting a common template.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Conservative activists have emphasized parental control and child protection, calling transition care harmful, an assertion rejected by the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.ama-assn.org/press-center/press-releases/ama-reinforces-opposition-restrictions-transgender-medical-care" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">American Medical Association</a>, the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.psychiatry.org/File%20Library/About-APA/Organization-Documents-Policies/Policies/Position-Transgender-Gender-Diverse-Youth.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">American Psychiatric Association</a>, the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.aap.org/en/news-room/news-releases/aap/2022/statement-from-the-american-academy-of-pediatrics-and-the-oklahoma-chapter-of-the-american-academy-of-pediatrics-on-gender-affirming-care/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">American Academy of Pediatrics</a> and other medical groups. Transgender people have higher rates of depression and suicide, and research shows that transition care — which can involve puberty blockers, hormones or surgery, though minors rarely receive surgery — can improve mental health.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Some activists and politicians also say exposing young people to transgender identities, whether through a book reading by a drag performer or a classroom discussion, “sexualizes” them — an echo of anti-gay campaigns dating to the 1970s, which cast gay people as preying on children.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div class="css-79elbk" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper"><div class="css-z3e15g" data-testid="photoviewer-wrapper-hidden"></div><div data-testid="photoviewer-children" class="css-1a48zt4 e11si9ry5"><figure class="img-sz-medium css-d754w4 e1g7ppur0" aria-label="media" role="group"><div class="css-1xdhyk6 erfvjey0"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Image</span><div class="css-nwd8t8" data-testid="lazy-image"><div data-testid="lazyimage-container" style="height:257.77777777777777px"></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-xaa95i ewdxa0s0"><span aria-hidden="false" class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">L.G.B.T.Q. rights groups protesting a bill in South Carolina last year to ban transgender athletes from competing in girls’ sports.</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span><span aria-hidden="false">Jeffrey Collins/Associated Press</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div></div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But the bills arriving in legislatures show a movement expanding beyond what it pitched itself as.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The 25-year-olds who would be unable to receive transition care in Oklahoma and South Carolina are not, after all, children. An <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://apps.azleg.gov/BillStatus/BillOverview/78083" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Arizona bill</a> would ban drag shows on Sunday mornings whether or not minors were around. (The lawmakers who introduced those bills did not respond to requests for comment.)</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Matt Sharp, senior counsel and state government relations national director for the Alliance Defending Freedom, said his group believed “gender ideology attacks the truth that every person is either male or female.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">And Mr. Schilling, of the American Principles Project, confirmed that his organization’s long-term goal was to eliminate transition care. The initial focus on children, he said, was a matter of “going where the consensus is.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Cathryn Oakley, the state legislative director and senior counsel at the Human Rights Campaign, said the bills disproved the notion that protecting children had ever been the motivation.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s not because they don’t think folks can give adequate consent,” she said, pointing also to the bills’ exceptions: The same treatments banned for transgender children would be allowed for intersex children, whose sexual organs, hormones or chromosomes fall on the spectrum between male and female. “They don’t want people to get this care because they don’t think being trans is real.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Even as bills reach further, many lawmakers still frame their arguments around children.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">State Representative Jim Olsen, the sponsor of <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://webserver1.lsb.state.ok.us/cf_pdf/2023-24%20INT/hB/HB1011%20INT.PDF" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">the Oklahoma ban on transition care up to age 21</a>, said in an interview, “The desire is simply to protect young people from choices that later on in their life can be mentally and physically harmful and some of them will grow to regret.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mr. Olsen presented studies from <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0016885" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Sweden</a> and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://eje.bioscientifica.com/view/journals/eje/164/4/635.xml" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">the Netherlands</a> as evidence that transition care increased suicide risk, but the lead authors of both studies, Cecilia Dhejne and Henk Asscheman, said this misrepresented their findings. (“The conclusion that cross-sex hormone treatment increases suicide rate is completely wrong,” Dr. Asscheman said.) Told this, Mr. Olsen maintained that his conclusion was “reasonable.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Even among Republicans, support for aggressive legislation is not universal. When Arkansas passed its ban on transition care for minors in 2021, it did so over <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/05/us/politics/asa-hutchinson-veto-transgender-bill.html" title="">the veto of its Republican governor</a>, Asa Hutchinson. Last year, the governors of <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/22/us/utah-governor-transgender-athlete-ban.html" title="">Utah</a> and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/21/us/eric-holcomb-transgender-sports.html" title="">Indiana</a> vetoed bills restricting transgender students’ participation in sports.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Rarely has so much fear and anger been directed at so few,” Gov. Spencer Cox of Utah <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1emUTfFEbmNmSdW9UhhsRAseVNr4cPIv9/view" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">wrote</a>. “I don’t understand what they are going through or why they feel the way they do. But I want them to live.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Beyond health care, lawmakers are reaching deeper into transgender people’s lives.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The bill <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://billstatus.ls.state.ms.us/documents/2023/pdf/SB/2001-2099/SB2076IN.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">in Mississippi</a> defining sex as immutably set at birth would have implications for, among other things, accommodations from bathrooms to sports teams to prisons.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">And in addition to the bill <a class="css-yywogo" href="http://www.wvlegislature.gov/Bill_Text_HTML/2023_SESSIONS/RS/bills/sb252%20intr.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">in West Virginia</a> that would define “transvestite and/or transgender exposure” around minors as obscene, bills in at least nine states would restrict drag shows, and some define them very broadly.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">One <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://nebraskalegislature.gov/FloorDocs/108/PDF/Intro/LB371.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">in Nebraska</a>, for instance, would apply to any show whose “main aspect” is “a performer which exhibits a gender identity that is different than the performer’s gender assigned at birth using clothing, makeup, or other physical markers; and the performer sings, lip syncs, dances, or otherwise performs before an audience for entertainment.”</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">State Senator Dave Murman of Nebraska said concerns that his bill’s definition encompassed any performance by a transgender person were “ridiculous” because transgender people “are not engaged in performance just by being transgender.” He did not respond to a follow-up question about transgender comedians or transgender singers.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Advocates said the new bills told transgender people that their identities were debatable, and their rights a political football.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“We want to bring this conversation back to the reality of the people that are being directly affected,” said Casey Pick, senior fellow for advocacy and government affairs at the Trevor Project, a suicide prevention organization for L.G.B.T.Q. youths. “The rhetoric is vicious and hard to hear, and it filters down. It filters through a constant media cycle on down to dining room tables and family holidays where youth are feeling excluded.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.thetrevorproject.org/blog/new-poll-emphasizes-negative-impacts-of-anti-lgbtq-policies-on-lgbtq-youth/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">a recent poll</a> conducted by Morning Consult for the Trevor Project, 86 percent of transgender and nonbinary youths said debates over state laws had hurt their mental health.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Ms. Oakley of the Human Rights Campaign said this was why she disliked the framing of anti-transgender legislation as a culture war.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s not a war,” she said, “when there are powerful politicians on one side and there are terrified kids on the other.”</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">Audio produced by <!-- -->Kate Winslett<!-- -->.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><div></div></div></section><div></div><div></div><div></div><div id="bottom-sheet-sensor"><div></div></div><div><div id="bottom-wrapper" class="css-c4adj9"><div id="bottom-slug" class="css-l9onyx"><p>Advertisement</p></div><a href="#after-bottom" class="css-1ly73wi">Continue reading the main story</a><div class="ad bottom-wrapper oembed.title: G.O.P. State Lawmakers Push a Growing Wave of Anti-Transgender Bills
oembed.summary: Four states could ban transition care into young adulthood. Lawmakers in several others want to restrict drag shows in ways that could affect transgender performers broadly. It’s part of a long-term plan.
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2023%2F01%2F25%2Fus%2Fpolitics%2Ftransgender-laws-republicans.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="G.O.P. State Lawmakers Push a Growing Wave of Anti-Transgender Bills" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>

readabilityObject.title: G.O.P. State Lawmakers Push a Growing Wave of Anti-Transgender Bills
readabilityObject.content:
Four states could ban transition care into young adulthood. Lawmakers in several others want to restrict drag shows in ways that could affect transgender performers broadly. It’s part of a long-term plan.

Published Jan. 25, 2023Updated Jan. 30, 2023

To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

Over the past three years, Republican state lawmakers have put forward a barrage of bills to regulate the lives of transgender youths, restricting the sports teams they can play on, bathrooms they can use and medical care they can receive.

But even by those standards, the start of the 2023 legislative season stands out for the aggressiveness with which lawmakers are pushing into new territory.

The bills they have proposed — more than 150 in at least 25 states — include bans on transition care into young adulthood; restrictions on drag shows using definitions that could broadly encompass performances by transgender people; measures that would prevent teachers in many cases from using names or pronouns matching students’ gender identities; and requirements that schools out transgender students to their parents.

The flood of legislation is part of a long-term campaign by national groups that see transgender rights as an issue on which they can harness voter anger — as with the campaigns against remote learning and critical race theory that reshaped many school boards and lifted Republicans in Virginia’s elections in 2021 — though the midterm elections provided little evidence of it.

“This is a political winner,” said Terry Schilling, the president of the conservative American Principles Project, arguing that more voters would have been swayed had many Republicans not “shied away” from the subject.

The potential consequences for transgender people, for whom harassment and threats have become common and suicide rates are high, are profound. Many express a sense that the power of their government is being turned against them as they try to live their lives.

“We have shifted this conversation so incredibly far in the direction of restrictions on trans people’s autonomy and rights in a way that was completely unfathomable to many of us even just three or four years ago,” said Chase Strangio, a lawyer at the American Civil Liberties Union.

Legislation in Oklahoma and South Carolina would make it a felony to provide hormonal or surgical transition treatment to transgender people younger than 26 — an uncharted incursion into adults’ health care. Other bills in both states, and in Kansas and Mississippi, would ban such care up to age 21. And bills in more than a dozen states would ban it for minors, which Arkansas was the first to do in 2021, against the consensus of major medical organizations.

A bill in Mississippi — declaring that “separate is not inherently unequal,” an allusion to Plessy v. Ferguson, the 1896 ruling in which the Supreme Court upheld segregation — would define sex as immutably set at birth, denying transgender identities under state law. A measure in West Virginia would define “any transvestite and/or transgender exposure, performances or display” as obscene, potentially outlawing transgender people’s presence around children.

Not all, or perhaps even most, of the measures will become law, and those that do may face legal challenges. But as of Tuesday, more than 10 bills had made it through committee, and at least six had passed a full legislative chamber, according to Erin Reed, a legislative researcher.

She and other transgender advocates said they worried that the most aggressive bills, even if never enacted, could ease the passage of slightly less aggressive bills by making them seem like compromises.

“I really hope that people don’t allow that to happen,” said Ms. Reed, who is transgender. “Because these bills still target trans people who will then have to suffer the consequences.”

The people pushing these laws include Christian conservatives — among them some of the same figures who fought the legalization of gay marriage — and political operatives. They have organized and lobbied through groups like the Alliance Defending Freedom, the Family Policy Alliance, the Heritage Foundation and the American Principles Project.

Many bills contain nearly identical language, suggesting a common template.

Conservative activists have emphasized parental control and child protection, calling transition care harmful, an assertion rejected by the American Medical Association, the American Psychiatric Association, the American Academy of Pediatrics and other medical groups. Transgender people have higher rates of depression and suicide, and research shows that transition care — which can involve puberty blockers, hormones or surgery, though minors rarely receive surgery — can improve mental health.

Some activists and politicians also say exposing young people to transgender identities, whether through a book reading by a drag performer or a classroom discussion, “sexualizes” them — an echo of anti-gay campaigns dating to the 1970s, which cast gay people as preying on children.

But the bills arriving in legislatures show a movement expanding beyond what it pitched itself as.

The 25-year-olds who would be unable to receive transition care in Oklahoma and South Carolina are not, after all, children. An Arizona bill would ban drag shows on Sunday mornings whether or not minors were around. (The lawmakers who introduced those bills did not respond to requests for comment.)

Matt Sharp, senior counsel and state government relations national director for the Alliance Defending Freedom, said his group believed “gender ideology attacks the truth that every person is either male or female.”

And Mr. Schilling, of the American Principles Project, confirmed that his organization’s long-term goal was to eliminate transition care. The initial focus on children, he said, was a matter of “going where the consensus is.”

Cathryn Oakley, the state legislative director and senior counsel at the Human Rights Campaign, said the bills disproved the notion that protecting children had ever been the motivation.

“It’s not because they don’t think folks can give adequate consent,” she said, pointing also to the bills’ exceptions: The same treatments banned for transgender children would be allowed for intersex children, whose sexual organs, hormones or chromosomes fall on the spectrum between male and female. “They don’t want people to get this care because they don’t think being trans is real.”

Even as bills reach further, many lawmakers still frame their arguments around children.

State Representative Jim Olsen, the sponsor of the Oklahoma ban on transition care up to age 21, said in an interview, “The desire is simply to protect young people from choices that later on in their life can be mentally and physically harmful and some of them will grow to regret.”

Mr. Olsen presented studies from Sweden and the Netherlands as evidence that transition care increased suicide risk, but the lead authors of both studies, Cecilia Dhejne and Henk Asscheman, said this misrepresented their findings. (“The conclusion that cross-sex hormone treatment increases suicide rate is completely wrong,” Dr. Asscheman said.) Told this, Mr. Olsen maintained that his conclusion was “reasonable.”

Even among Republicans, support for aggressive legislation is not universal. When Arkansas passed its ban on transition care for minors in 2021, it did so over the veto of its Republican governor, Asa Hutchinson. Last year, the governors of Utah and Indiana vetoed bills restricting transgender students’ participation in sports.

“Rarely has so much fear and anger been directed at so few,” Gov. Spencer Cox of Utah wrote. “I don’t understand what they are going through or why they feel the way they do. But I want them to live.”

Beyond health care, lawmakers are reaching deeper into transgender people’s lives.

The bill in Mississippi defining sex as immutably set at birth would have implications for, among other things, accommodations from bathrooms to sports teams to prisons.

And in addition to the bill in West Virginia that would define “transvestite and/or transgender exposure” around minors as obscene, bills in at least nine states would restrict drag shows, and some define them very broadly.

One in Nebraska, for instance, would apply to any show whose “main aspect” is “a performer which exhibits a gender identity that is different than the performer’s gender assigned at birth using clothing, makeup, or other physical markers; and the performer sings, lip syncs, dances, or otherwise performs before an audience for entertainment.”

State Senator Dave Murman of Nebraska said concerns that his bill’s definition encompassed any performance by a transgender person were “ridiculous” because transgender people “are not engaged in performance just by being transgender.” He did not respond to a follow-up question about transgender comedians or transgender singers.

Advocates said the new bills told transgender people that their identities were debatable, and their rights a political football.

“We want to bring this conversation back to the reality of the people that are being directly affected,” said Casey Pick, senior fellow for advocacy and government affairs at the Trevor Project, a suicide prevention organization for L.G.B.T.Q. youths. “The rhetoric is vicious and hard to hear, and it filters down. It filters through a constant media cycle on down to dining room tables and family holidays where youth are feeling excluded.”

In a recent poll conducted by Morning Consult for the Trevor Project, 86 percent of transgender and nonbinary youths said debates over state laws had hurt their mental health.

Ms. Oakley of the Human Rights Campaign said this was why she disliked the framing of anti-transgender legislation as a culture war.

“It’s not a war,” she said, “when there are powerful politicians on one side and there are terrified kids on the other.”

Audio produced by Kate Winslett.

Lawmakers in several others want to restrict drag shows in ways that could affect transgender performers broadly. It’s part of a long-term plan.Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma signing a bill last year that bars transgender girls and women from girls’ and women’s sports teams. A new bill would make it a felony to provide transition treatment to transgender people younger than 26.Credit...Sean Murphy/Associated PressPublished Jan. 25, 2023Updated Jan. 30, 2023Listen to This ArticleTo hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.Over the past three years, Republican state lawmakers have put forward a barrage of bills to regulate the lives of transgender youths, restricting the sports teams they can play on, bathrooms they can use and medical care they can receive.But even by those standards, the start of the 2023 legislative season stands out for the aggressiveness with which lawmakers are pushing into new territory.The bills they have proposed — more than 150 in at least 25 states — include bans on transition care into young adulthood; restrictions on drag shows using definitions that could broadly encompass performances by transgender people; measures that would prevent teachers in many cases from using names or pronouns matching students’ gender identities; and requirements that schools out transgender students to their parents.The flood of legislation is part of a long-term campaign by national groups that see transgender rights as an issue on which they can harness voter anger — as with the campaigns against remote learning and critical race theory that reshaped many school boards and lifted Republicans in Virginia’s elections in 2021 — though the midterm elections provided little evidence of it.“This is a political winner,” said Terry Schilling, the president of the conservative American Principles Project, arguing that more voters would have been swayed had many Republicans not “shied away” from the subject.The potential consequences for transgender people, for whom harassment and threats have become common and suicide rates are high, are profound. Many express a sense that the power of their government is being turned against them as they try to live their lives.“We have shifted this conversation so incredibly far in the direction of restrictions on trans people’s autonomy and rights in a way that was completely unfathomable to many of us even just three or four years ago,” said Chase Strangio, a lawyer at the American Civil Liberties Union.Legislation in Oklahoma and South Carolina would make it a felony to provide hormonal or surgical transition treatment to transgender people younger than 26 — an uncharted incursion into adults’ health care. Other bills in both states, and in Kansas and Mississippi, would ban such care up to age 21. And bills in more than a dozen states would ban it for minors, which Arkansas was the first to do in 2021, against the consensus of major medical organizations.A bill in Mississippi — declaring that “separate is not inherently unequal,” an allusion to Plessy v. Ferguson, the 1896 ruling in which the Supreme Court upheld segregation — would define sex as immutably set at birth, denying transgender identities under state law. A measure in West Virginia would define “any transvestite and/or transgender exposure, performances or display” as obscene, potentially outlawing transgender people’s presence around children.Not all, or perhaps even most, of the measures will become law, and those that do may face legal challenges. But as of Tuesday, more than 10 bills had made it through committee, and at least six had passed a full legislative chamber, according to Erin Reed, a legislative researcher.She and other transgender advocates said they worried that the most aggressive bills, even if never enacted, could ease the passage of slightly less aggressive bills by making them seem like compromises.“I really hope that people don’t allow that to happen,” said Ms. Reed, who is transgender. “Because these bills still target trans people who will then have to suffer the consequences.”The people pushing these laws include Christian conservatives — among them some of the same figures who fought the legalization of gay marriage — and political operatives. They have organized and lobbied through groups like the Alliance Defending Freedom, the Family Policy Alliance, the Heritage Foundation and the American Principles Project.Many bills contain nearly identical language, suggesting a common template.Conservative activists have emphasized parental control and child protection, calling transition care harmful, an assertion rejected by the American Medical Association, the American Psychiatric Association, the American Academy of Pediatrics and other medical groups. An Arizona bill would ban drag shows on Sunday mornings whether or not minors were around. (The lawmakers who introduced those bills did not respond to requests for comment.)Matt Sharp, senior counsel and state government relations national director for the Alliance Defending Freedom, said his group believed “gender ideology attacks the truth that every person is either male or female.”And Mr. Schilling, of the American Principles Project, confirmed that his organization’s long-term goal was to eliminate transition care. The initial focus on children, he said, was a matter of “going where the consensus is.”Cathryn Oakley, the state legislative director and senior counsel at the Human Rights Campaign, said the bills disproved the notion that protecting children had ever been the motivation.“It’s not because they don’t think folks can give adequate consent,” she said, pointing also to the bills’ exceptions: The same treatments banned for transgender children would be allowed for intersex children, whose sexual organs, hormones or chromosomes fall on the spectrum between male and female. “They don’t want people to get this care because they don’t think being trans is real.”Even as bills reach further, many lawmakers still frame their arguments around children.State Representative Jim Olsen, the sponsor of the Oklahoma ban on transition care up to age 21, said in an interview, “The desire is simply to protect young people from choices that later on in their life can be mentally and physically harmful and some of them will grow to regret.”Mr. Olsen presented studies from Sweden and the Netherlands as evidence that transition care increased suicide risk, but the lead authors of both studies, Cecilia Dhejne and Henk Asscheman, said this misrepresented their findings. (“The conclusion that cross-sex hormone treatment increases suicide rate is completely wrong,” Dr. Asscheman said.) Told this, Mr. Olsen maintained that his conclusion was “reasonable.”Even among Republicans, support for aggressive legislation is not universal. When Arkansas passed its ban on transition care for minors in 2021, it did so over the veto of its Republican governor, Asa Hutchinson. Last year, the governors of Utah and Indiana vetoed bills restricting transgender students’ participation in sports.“Rarely has so much fear and anger been directed at so few,” Gov. Spencer Cox of Utah wrote. “I don’t understand what they are going through or why they feel the way they do. But I want them to live.”Beyond health care, lawmakers are reaching deeper into transgender people’s lives.The bill in Mississippi defining sex as immutably set at birth would have implications for, among other things, accommodations from bathrooms to sports teams to prisons.And in addition to the bill in West Virginia that would define “transvestite and/or transgender exposure” around minors as obscene, bills in at least nine states would restrict drag shows, and some define them very broadly.One in Nebraska, for instance, would apply to any show whose “main aspect” is “a performer which exhibits a gender identity that is different than the performer’s gender assigned at birth using clothing, makeup, or other physical markers; and the performer sings, lip syncs, dances, or otherwise performs before an audience for entertainment.”State Senator Dave Murman of Nebraska said concerns that his bill’s definition encompassed any performance by a transgender person were “ridiculous” because transgender people “are not engaged in performance just by being transgender.” He did not respond to a follow-up question about transgender comedians or transgender singers.Advocates said the new bills told transgender people that their identities were debatable, and their rights a political football.“We want to bring this conversation back to the reality of the people that are being directly affected,” said Casey Pick, senior fellow for advocacy and government affairs at the Trevor Project, a suicide prevention organization for L.G.B.T.Q. youths. “The rhetoric is vicious and hard to hear, and it filters down.
